Award.AwardTitle: Biological Invasions, Range Pinning, and Adaptive Evolution of Quantitative Traits
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research focuses on the development and analysis of mathematical models of adaptive evolution in populations distributed over a territory. The main focus is on quantitative traits (characteristics like body size affected by many genes), which have been studied less in this context than traits determined by a single gene. A combination of rigorous pencil-and-paper analysis and computer simulation is used to provide insight into how evolution affects the speed, success and ultimate extent of biological invasions. The results can inform thinking on environmental management issues, such as deciding how to allocate conservation measures among marginal or central populations. By elucidating general principles that can guide the construction and interpretation of more specific models for management of natural populations, this research helps to address the economically important environmental challenges of management of invasive species and response to climate change.

Mathematically, this project will result in the development of new methods for proving existence and stability of localized solutions (representing populations whose territory is not expanding) and traveling waves (representing invasive species), for a class of differential equations and similar systems that do not admit analysis via commonly employed methods. Specifically, this analysis will result in the development of new methods for proving existence and stability of localized solutions and traveling waves, for a class of biologically meaningful systems that do not admit analysis via phase plane or comparison principle methods. Since those techniques cannot readily be extended to many systems or equations, progress in devising alternative approaches will help to fill a significant gap. Biologically, the resulting analysis of general range dynamics models involving quantitative traits will contribute to understanding of the interplay between gene flow and numerous other demographic, genetic and environmental factors that help shape a population's distribution in space and time. It will highlight factors, such as long-distance dispersal and habitat patchiness, that are not yet integrated into the relevant theory. This work will help show how incorporating adaptive genetic change into invasion models alters the predictions of such models.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Why do species occupy the geographical ranges that they do? Sometimes the region is obvious—a land animal cannot colonize the ocean. But in many cases the reason is more subtle. For example, an invasive butterfly species might first appear in Florida and extend its range to southern Ontario, but be unable to go further north. It seems natural to conclude that the butterfly’s range in Canada is limited because of the cold climate. But the butterfly had adapted to colder and colder temperatures as it moved northward from Florida, so why couldn’t it adapt just a little more and extend its range further still? 
Mathematicians and theoretical biologists explore the factors that determine species’ range boundaries with mathematical models that predict, from the current or initial state of a species population, for example its location and population density, the future states of that population . (Technically, these models often take the form of systems of partial differential equations or similar models called integrodifference equations.) In our project, we used such models to explore how the genetic makeup, demographic characteristics (e.g. birth and death rates) and initial spatial location of a population combine to influence the rate at which a species’ range may grow or shrink and the location of the range that it eventually settles into. 
We explored the behavior of models that incorporate evolution by natural selection, demographics, spatial spread, and in some cases competition between species. Genetics and evolution are widely recognized as potential major factors affecting the fate of invasive species, but there is still much that we do not know about how these they interact with other factors to help determine species’ range boundaries. 
We used computer simulations of several models to predict the behavior of invasive species, based on their initial genetic and other characteristics. By doing so, we discovered new conditions that can lead to “range pinning”—the establishment of permanent range boundaries—in our models. We also discovered novel behavior of some such models—for example, we found circumstances under which a population confined to a small range can suddenly spread over a large range due to a transient change in the environment, but not return to the small range once the environment returns to its previous state.
We also proved mathematical theorems that helped clarify the properties of solutions to our equations. This is important because computer simulations can sometimes be misleading, reflecting quirks in the computer proram rather than actual features of of the equations’ solutions that provide predictions about how the species behaves. 
Most of our work was on general, relatively uncomplicated models This allowed us to identify general principles which generate hypotheses that can be tested by empirical invaison biology researchers. In turn, theoretical and empirical studies together can help guide practitioners such as wildlife managers or crop pest control specialists in designing detailed models of specific populations. Thus, in addition to contributing to science, our studies should ultimately improve predictions of the effects of possible conservation or pest control measures. We also contributed to the development of a highly skilled and diverse STEM (science, technology, engineering and mathematics) workforce by training two postdoctoral fellows and two undergraduate research assistants.
